summary: This document is a series of forwarded emails from whistleblower Christopher J. Dilorio to various recipients, primarily alleging widespread corruption, obstruction, and criminal facilitation by the SEC and other government agencies. Dilorio details specific claims related to Knight Capital/Virtu Financial (NITE), Blackstone, Eastman Kodak (KODK), and various money laundering shell companies, while accusing SEC officials of protecting certain individuals and entities from investigation.

persons.name: Christopher J. Dilorio
persons.context: The author of the emails, making extensive allegations of SEC corruption, obstruction of justice, and facilitation of financial fraud related to Knight Capital, Blackstone, and various shell companies.

persons.name: Janey
persons.context: Frequent recipient of Dilorio's emails; accused of failing to distribute his whistleblower information within the SEC and being part of the obstruction.

persons.name: Hoecker
persons.context: Referenced as the 'grossly corrupt SEC IG'; accused of conducting sham investigations and being part of the cover-up of Dilorio's allegations.

persons.name: Jay Clayton
persons.context: Accused of undisclosed conflicts of interest related to his former firm Sullivan & Cromwell and its clients (like NITE), and of facilitating fraud.

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: Former colleague of Jay Clayton at Sullivan & Cromwell; accused of playing a key role in the fraud related to Knight/NITE and Net Element.

persons.name: Steve Schwarzman
persons.context: Described as being high on the SEC's 'do not investigate list'; implicated in the Knight Capital bailout and the KODK loan deal. Connected to Trump and Epstein.

persons.name: Jason New
persons.context: Blackstone executive on the Kodak board; involved in the internal investigation of the KODK loan and linked to the alleged fraud.

persons.name: Anthony Zakel
persons.context: Newly hired Inspector General for the U.S. International Development Finance Corporation (DFC), mentioned in relation to the review of the Kodak loan.

persons.name: Adam Boehler
persons.context: Referred to as 'Kushner roommate Boehler'; praised the hiring of IG Zakel while being investigated for the $765 million Kodak loan.

persons.name: Doug Cifu
persons.context: CEO of Virtu Financial (which owns NITE); accused of being a former boss/colleague of SEC's Lara Mehraban and overseeing accounting fraud at NITE.

persons.name: Lara Shalov Mehraban
persons.context: SECNY Director; accused of having a conflict due to her former association with Doug Cifu at Paul Weiss and obstructing investigations into NITE/IBKR.

persons.name: Alex Ioffe
persons.context: Former CFO of Interactive Brokers (IBKR) who became CFO of Virtu; implicated in the IBKR SARs failure complaint.

persons.name: Dick Best
persons.context: New Director of SECNY, formerly at FINRA; accused of criminally obstructing investigations into Dilorio's claims related to the BBH AML case.

persons.name: David Urban
persons.context: Trump campaign manager; serves on the board of NITE and money laundering shell FSD Pharma (HUGE); implicated in SEC-facilitated pump-and-dumps.

persons.name: Michael Farkas
persons.context: Bag man' and CEO of Blink Charging (fka New Image Concepts), a alleged money laundering shell; linked to Milken, Trump, and Epstein.

persons.name: Jonathan Farkas
persons.context: Trump fundraiser and Epstein business partner; suggested to be related to Michael Farkas.

persons.name: Bill Richardson
persons.context: Linked to Blink Charging and to Jeffrey Epstein's Zorro Ranch in New Mexico.

persons.name: Justin Keener
persons.context: Bag man' barred by FINRA but allegedly still active; involved in money laundering shells like Blink Charging and referenced in Dilorio's TCR.

persons.name: Joshua Sason
persons.context: Bag man' involved in Hanover/Magna and various shell companies; subject of an SEC complaint which Dilorio claims is based on his information.

connections.description: Dilorio repeatedly sends allegations and appeals to SEC official Janey, accusing Janey of failing to distribute his information and being part of the obstruction.
Former colleagues at law firm Sullivan & Cromwell; Dilorio alleges they collaborated in fraud related to NITE and Net Element.
Schwarzman is CEO of Blackstone; New is a Blackstone executive placed on the Kodak board.
Alleged former boss/colleague relationship at law firm Paul Weiss; Dilorio claims this creates a conflict of interest in Mehraban's SEC investigations of Virtu/NITE.
Boehler, as DFC CEO, praised the hiring of IG Zakel, who would then be investigating Boehler's role in the Kodak loan.
Described as 'BFFs'; Schwarzman is a prolific GOP donor and connected to Trump's policies and appointments.
Suggested to be related; both are connected to Trump fundraising and alleged financial fraud.
Linked to Epstein through the latter's Zorro Ranch in New Mexico.

events.title: Knight Capital Trading Glitch and Bailout
events.description: A trading glitch caused Knight Capital's stock to collapse from over $10 to nearly $2.50, followed by a bailout by a consortium including Blackstone, Goldman Sachs, and Jefferies.

events.title: Kodak $765 Million Loan Announcement
events.description: The U.S. International Development Finance Corporation (DFC) announced a planned $765 million loan to Eastman Kodak to produce pharmaceutical ingredients, causing the stock to surge.

events.title: DFC IG Review of Kodak Loan
events.description: The DFC Inspector General announced a review of the proposed $765 million loan to Kodak.

events.title: Dilorio's Formal Appeal Denial
events.description: Christopher Dilorio received a preliminary denial of his Opco whistleblower award application, which he claims was fabricated to run out the clock.

events.title: Blink Charging Pump and Dump
events.description: Blink Charging issued a press release about a grant for charging stations, driving the stock up 27% without filing a required 8-K, which Dilorio alleges was a fraudulent pump-and-dump.

keyFacts: The whistleblower, Christopher Dilorio, alleges a massive, ongoing conspiracy involving the SEC, Blackstone, and others to obstruct investigations into financial fraud at Knight Capital/Virtu (NITE) and facilitate money laundering through shell companies.

Dilorio claims the SEC created a new rule (Rule 240.21F-18) specifically to deny his whistleblower award by claiming SEC staff never saw his information, which he calls 'The Christopher J Dilorio Rule.'

The document details specific allegations about the $765 million DFC loan to Eastman Kodak (KODK), implicating Blackstone's Steve Schwarzman and Jason New, and DFC CEO Adam Boehler (a Kushner associate) in potential fraud.
Dilorio asserts that NITE (Knight/Virtu) is perpetually insolvent due to illegal naked short selling of OTC market shells to facilitate money laundering, and that the SEC actively enables this fraud.
Multiple individuals are named as being on the SEC's alleged 'do not investigate list,' including Steve Schwarzman, Blackstone, and others involved with Knight Capital and the Kodak deal.
